of insurance policies, to regulate, promote and ensure orderly growth of the insurance 
industry and for ma tters connected therewith or incidental thereto and further to amend 
the Insurance Act, 1938, the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956 and the General 
Insurance Business (Nationalisation) Act, 1972.

__data__.text: The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority Act, 1999 is an Act to provide for the establishment of an Authority to protect the interests of holders of insurance policies, to regulate, promote and ensure orderly growth of the insurance industry and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto. The Act extends to the whole of India and came into force on 19.4.2000. The Authority consists of a Chairperson and not more than five whole-time members and not more than four part-time members appointed by the Central Government. The Chairperson and other members shall hold office for a term of five years and shall be eligible for reappointment. The Authority shall meet at such time and places and shall observe such rules and procedures in regard to transaction of business at its meetings. The Authority shall have the powers of general superintendence and direction in respect of all administrative matters and shall be responsible for regulating, promoting and ensuring orderly growth of the insurance industry. The Authority shall maintain proper accounts and other relevant records and prepare an annual statement of accounts. The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority Fund shall be constituted and applied for meeting the salaries, allowances and other remuneration of the members, officers and other employees of the Authority and the other expenses of the Authority in connection with the discharge of its functions and for the purposes of this Act. The Central Government may issue directions to the Authority on questions of policy and may supersede the Authority if it is unable to discharge the functions or perform the duties imposed on it by or under the provisions of this Act.

The IRDA Act as amended by Insurance Laws (Amendment) Act 2015 provides protection of action taken in good faith for the Central Government, officers, members, and other employees of the Authority. It also allows the Authority to delegate powers and functions to the Chairperson or other members or officers of the Authority, and to form committees of members. The Act also allows for the establishment of an Insurance Advisory Committee, and for the making of rules and regulations. It also amends the Insurance Act 1938, the Life Insurance Corporation Act 1956, and the General Insurance Business (Nationalisation) Act 1972. The amendments include the substitution of "Authority" for "Controller" in most cases, the introduction of an Indian insurance company, the introduction of a requirement for a paid-up equity capital of Rs. 100 crores for life or general insurance, and the introduction of a requirement for a paid-up equity capital of Rs. 200 crores for re-insurance. It also introduces a requirement for promoters to divest excess shareholding in an Indian insurance company.

The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority Act, 1999, was amended by the Insurance Laws (Amendment) Act 2015. This amendment included changes to Sections 13, 28A, 28B, 31B, 32A, 35, 36, 37, 42, 64V, and 64VA. These changes included the requirement for insurers to prepare a balance sheet, profit and loss account, separate account of receipts and payments, and revenue account in accordance with regulations made by the Authority. It also included the requirement for insurers to undertake a certain percentage of life and general insurance business in the rural or social sector, as specified by the Authority. Furthermore, the amendment included changes to the qualifications and licensing of surveyors and loss assessors, as well as the required solvency margin for insurers.

The Insurance Regulatory and Development Authority (IRDA) Act, 1999, was amended by the Insurance Laws (Amendment) Act, 2015. The amendments included changes to sections 2B, 2C, 6, 70, 95, 101A, 101B, 102-105, 110H, 114, 114A, and 24A of the IRDA Act. These changes included modifications to the plan proposed by an insurer, deeming an insurer insolvent if they do not comply with the provisions of the Act, the passing of examinations to act as an insurance agent, the power of the Authority to make regulations, and the ceasing of the exclusive privilege of the Corporation and the acquiring companies of carrying on general insurance business in India.
